results.abstract: Article on Fashion Insider Ken, newest addition to Barbie Fashion Model Collection; photo (M)

headline.main: Memo to Barbie: You Aren't The Only Model Ken Knows

results.snippet: APOLOGIES to Barbie, but if her new best friend, Fashion Insider Ken, is so deep inside then how come he looks like a frump?     Fashion Insider Ken is the newest addition to the Barbie Fashion Model Collection and its first male simulacrum ever....
results.lead_paragraph: APOLOGIES to Barbie, but if her new best friend, Fashion Insider Ken, is so deep inside then how come he looks like a frump? Fashion Insider Ken is the newest addition to the Barbie Fashion Model Collection and its first male simulacrum ever. There have been other Kens, of course, but not in this particular line of expensive ($99.95), 11 1/2-inch dolls for collectors, and never one who flashed his fashion credentials.

results.abstract: Interview with MIT scientist Dr Cynthia L Breazeal about her passion for robot design covers her early work on robots through to her more recent projects with robots that interact with humans; infant-like Kismet robot and Leonardo, her most ambitious project to date, are described; she explains her goal to produce robots that cooperate with and respond to people; photos (L)

headline.main: A Passion to Build a Better Robot, One With Social Skills and a Smile

results.snippet: Dr. Cynthia L. Breazeal of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is famous for her robots, not just because they they are programmed to perform specific tasks, but because they seem to have emotional as well as physical reactions to the world...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Cynthia L. Breazeal of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is famous for her robots, not just because they they are programmed to perform specific tasks, but because they seem to have emotional as well as physical reactions to the world around them. They are ''embodied,'' she says, even ''sociable'' robots -- experimental machines that act like living creatures. As part of its design triennial, the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York is exhibiting a ''cyberfloral installation,'' by Dr. Breazeal, which features robotic flowers that sway when a human hand is near and glow in beautiful bright colors.

results.abstract: NASA administrator Sean O'Keefe says tests suggest that damage to space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to craft's destruction was so subtle that very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights will have to be developed (M)

headline.main: Tests Show Need to Overhaul Shuttle Checks, Official Says

results.snippet: Tests suggest that damage to the space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to the craft's destruction was so subtle that NASA will have to develop very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights, the agency's...
results.lead_paragraph: Tests suggest that damage to the space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to the craft's destruction was so subtle that NASA will have to develop very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights, the agency's administrator said today. The administrator, Sean O'Keefe, said he was sobered by the minuscule size of breaches in the leading edge of a test wing subjected to the impact of insulation foam at high speed, much as the Columbia was shortly after liftoff.

results.abstract: NASA officials say tiny object seen by astronaut Dr Edward T Lu drifting past window of International Space Station was probably indentification tag from external cable and poses no threat to station (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Space Object Identified As Tag

results.snippet: A tiny object seen drifting near the International Space Station was probably just an identification tag from an external power or data cable and poses no threat, NASA officials said. An astronaut, Dr. Edward T. Lu, saw the object drift past a window...
results.lead_paragraph: A tiny object seen drifting near the International Space Station was probably just an identification tag from an external power or data cable and poses no threat, NASA officials said. An astronaut, Dr. Edward T. Lu, saw the object drift past a window on Thursday, and said the object resembled one of the many metal tags attached to cables on the exterior of the space station, an agency spokesman, Kyle Herring, told The Houston Chronicle.

results.abstract: Space Adventures and Russian space agency to resume in 2004 or 2005 tourist flights to International Space Station, lifting moratorium imposed after Columbia shuttle disaster; plan to charge two tourists $20 million each still requires approval from National Aeronautics and Space Administration and European space station partners; photos (M)

headline.main: For Those Who Can Afford It, 2 New Chances to Fly to Space

results.snippet: An American company and the Russian space agency are to announce an agreement today to resume tourist flights to the International Space Station in 2004 or 2005, lifting a moratorium imposed after the Columbia shuttle disaster.    For $20 million...
results.lead_paragraph: An American company and the Russian space agency are to announce an agreement today to resume tourist flights to the International Space Station in 2004 or 2005, lifting a moratorium imposed after the Columbia shuttle disaster. For $20 million each, travelers will have the chance to take part in what could be thought of as really extreme travel: a notoriously rough flight, cramped quarters and food that can make airline fare look appetizing. But the view is very, very nice.

results.abstract: Prof Matthew B Koss Op-Ed article on space shuttle Columbia disaster questions value of risking lives in manned space projects; notes many of scientific experiments used to justify projects do not require astronaut involvement; holds main purpose of astronauts is to sell space program; drawing (M)

headline.main: How Science Brought Down the Shuttle

results.snippet: As a scientist whose experiments were carried out on three missions of the space shuttle Columbia, I have been following with great interest the findings of the board looking into the shuttle's demise. Though a piece of foam may be found ultimately...
results.lead_paragraph: As a scientist whose experiments were carried out on three missions of the space shuttle Columbia, I have been following with great interest the findings of the board looking into the shuttle's demise. Though a piece of foam may be found ultimately responsible, as the Columbia Accident Investigation Board announced last week, on some level I feel personally culpable for the loss of the seven astronauts. In-orbit experiments like mine have been used to justify manned space projects like the shuttle for decades. The truth is that the vast majority of scientific experiments conducted in orbit -- including my own -- do not require astronauts. The main reason for in-orbit experimentation is to observe how a scientific process works without gravity-driven influences. But almost all of these tests, save those that must be done on humans, can be controlled from the ground via computer or by robots in space. In fact, some of the best work is done this way when the crew is asleep, not moving about and causing vibrations.
